headline: LOSE MY NUMBER: McConnell revealed to have rejected Trump calls on Jan. 6th
author: Ty Ross
sentences:
I publicly congratulated President Biden on his victory and received a phone call after that from President Trump, and that’s the last time we’ve spoken.”
While the fact they haven’t “spoken” since December, that doesn’t mean he didn’t attempt to return the call.

Advertisement Above
Ever since the release of the White House call logs — turned over to the January 6th Select Committee while the pieces of the insurrection puzzle are still coming together — there are still more questions remaining than answers.

When prodded by a reporter as to why he refused Trump’s call, the always calculating McConnell said this:
“I’ve said repeatedly the last time I spoke to the president was the day after the Electoral College declared President Biden the winner.

After being yelled at during their last communication and publicly criticized and condemned by The Former Guy, I wouldn’t blame McConnell for not exactly being “eager” to be on the receiving end of more verbal abuse.
These former allies turned into adversaries, and the bromance officially ended after McConnell publicly congratulated President-Elect Joe Biden on his electoral college victory on December 15, 2020.
Then again, the fact that they haven’t means that the Dems still have a shot of retaining their majorities in Congress with a Republican opposition still split with divided loyalties.
Olsen’s law firm, the one he co-founded, wasted no time scrubbing his entire presence from the firm after his involvement with the legal efforts to keep Trump in office was revealed.
Virtually an unknown, Olsen endeared himself to Trump with crazy theories and jumped on Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton’s attempt to overturn election results.
Neither the aide nor McConnell have elaborated on exactly why the Senator rejected Trump’s call – nor have they given details on what was said in the message.
The 9:16 AM call came after a call to then-Vice President Mike Pence – at 9:02 AM, and before a call at 9:24 AM to Congressman Jim Jordan (R-OH).
According to Bob Woodward and Robert Costa, Trump asked McConnell “And this is the thanks I got?” He then complained “You never really got me.
Donald Trump’s first call, at 8:34 AM, was to former Navy Seal and special ops platoon commander (turned lawyer and MAGA cook), Kurt Olsen.

Sponsored Links
Of course, this begs the question – why would Trump possibly be calling McConnell on the morning of January 6th?
There was nothing for him to gain by engaging with a temper tantrum throwing man-child with one foot out the presidential door.

You don’t understand me.”
Sponsored Links
According to McConnell that would be the last conversation he had with Donald Trump.
The call logs show that at 10:40 AM, there was an unsuccessful attempt to reach McConnell – resulting in a voicemail.
But it is one particular call that stands out — a call to Senate Minority Leader, Mitch McConnell (R-KY).
There’s that, and quite frankly, McConnell simply didn’t — and doesn’t still — need Trump anymore.
The first attempt, however, was actually made almost an hour and a half prior, at 9:16 am.
If only the rest of the Republican Party would follow McConnell’s lead on ghosting Trump.
An aide for the Senator confirmed there was an attempt, and a message was left.
Trump called McConnell and berated him for his lack of loyalty and support.
Add your name to call on prosecutors to ARREST DONALD TRUMP for his crimes!
The usual suspects appear — Steve Bannon, Mark Meadows, and Rudy Giuliani.
There is no record that McConnell attempted to call his former boss back.

Sponsored Links
This did not bode well with the soon-to-be ex-President.
The public is finally getting a clearer picture of who was involved.
He had his federal judges and a stacked Supreme Court.
And that call McConnell declined to take.
Now, we need to know what was said.
That leaves even more questions.
But it’s highly unlikely.
